course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Government, Law and Society in China
course.description: This course introduces to students basic knowledge about the operation of the Chinese legal system or legal institutions. It examines how laws are used in the social, economic, and political activities of the Chinese people.

reviews.author: CY
reviews.comment_content:
Course description

             This course introduces to students the basic knowledge about the operation of the Chinese legal system or legal institutions. It examines how laws are used in the social, economic, and political activities of the Chinese people. The course focuses not on the Chinese laws per se but on how laws are used in people’s daily lives. Examples or cases will be used extensively in the course to illustrate the topics included. Major topics discussed in the course include the interactions between legal institutions and the party-state (i.e., the party and the government), the behavior of legal workers (e.g., judges, police officers), citizens’ use of civil lawsuits and administrative litigation, and some important mechanisms through which citizens or other social actors seek justice in China.



Learning outcomes

After taking this introductory course, students are expected to: (1) know about Chinese legal institutions and their functions; (2): be familiar with the ways legal disputes are resolved in China; (3) understand the mechanisms that can be exploited by citizens or other social actors to seek justice in Chinese society; and (4) be able to analyze basic legal issues in China.

Lectures

Week 1 Introduction: law and society in China

Wang Shaoguang, “The Problems of State Weakness,” Journal of Democracy, vol. 14, no. 1 (2003), pp. 36-42.



“The Cultural Revolution”

http://members.fortunecity.com/stalinmao/China/Cultural/Cultural.html





Week 2 Introduction to legal institutions in China

“China’s Judicial System: people’s courts, procuratorates, and public security,”
http://www.olemiss.edu/courses/pol324/chnjudic.htm



Richard Wong, “Why China chose the German instead of English legal system,”
South China Morning Post, October 13, 2015.





Week 3 Legal workers in China

Peerenboom, China’s Long March toward Rule of Law, pp. 290-302.



“Judging judges: To help build “the rule of law”, China is demoting judges,”
The Economists Sep 26th 2015





Week 4 Citizens’ use of law in China (I)

Yongshun Cai, “Social Conflicts and Modes of Action in China,” China Journal, vol. 59 (2008), pp. 62-82.



Zhang Shouzhi, “Litigation and enforcement in China: overview,” global.practicallaw.com/8-502-1965





Week 5   Citizens’ use of law in China (II)

Video: “The Story of Qiu Ju” (秋菊打官司) (English Subtitle).



Randall Peerenboom, China’s Long March toward Rule of Law, pp. 280-295.



Philip P. Pan, “In China, Turning the Law into the People’s Protector,” Washington Post, December 28, 2004; Page A01







Week 6 Suing the government in China

Peerenboom, China’s Long March toward Rule of Law, pp. 414-424.



Kevin O’Brien and Lianjiang Li, “Suing the local state: Administrative Litigation in Rural China,” China Journal, vol. 51 (2004), pp. 75-96.





Week 7 Law enforcement in China

Cindy Chu, “Human trafficking and Smuggling in China,” Journal of Contemporary China, vol. 20, no. 68 (2011), pp. 39-52.



Suggested reading:

Donald, Clarke, “The Execution of Civil Judgments in China,” China Quarterly, vol. 141 (1995), pp. 65 –81.



Xin He, “Debt-Collection in the Less Developed Regions of China: An Empirical Study from a Basic-Level Court in Shaanxi Province,” The China Quarterly, no. 206,





Seeking Justice in China: Redress Mechanisms



Week 8. Appeals and justice in China

Peerenboom, China’s Long March toward Rule of Law, pp. 302-312.



Jim Yardley, “Desperate Search for Justice: One Man vs. China,” The New York Times, 12 November 2005.



(Mid-Term Exam; it covers Lecture 1 to Lecture 6, second class of week 8)







Week 9 Petitions and justice in China

Yongshun Cai, “Managed Participation in China,” Political Science Quarterly, vol. 119, no. 3 (2004), pp. 425-452.



Suggested reading:

“The extrajudicial execution of Cao Haixin, a good citizen of Zhengzhou,” translated from Chinese by Joe Chung.





Week 10 Media and justice in China

Ben Liebman, “Changing media, changing courts” in Susan Shirk (ed.), Changing Media, Changing China (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2011), pp. 150-174.







Week 11 The People’s Congress

“The National People’s Congress,” http://www.china.org.cn/english/27743.htm



Suggested reading:

Pitman Potter, The Chinese Legal System (London: Routledge, 2001), pp. 16-26.





Week 12  Lawyers in China

Yongshun Cai and Songcai Yang, “State Power and Unbalanced Legal Development in China,” Journal of Contemporary China, vol. 14, no. 42 (2005), pp. 117-134.





Week 13 To the Court or to the Street: Social Protests in China
Chen, Chih-Jou Jay, “Growing Social Unrest and Emergent Protest Groups in China”, editor(s): Hsin-Huang Michael Hsiao and Cheng-Yi Lin, Rise of China: Beijing’s Strategies and Implications for the Asia-Pacific (London and New York: Routledge, 2009), pp. 87-106.



Suggested reading:

Kevin O’Brien, “Collective Action in the Chinese Countryside,” The China
Journal, no. 48 (2002), pp. 139-154.
reviews.comment_teaching: You can see from the lectures that the professor uses many examples in his teaching to spice up the content. I think he has a heart for teaching
reviews.comment_grading:
Students are expected to attend the lectures and complete the assigned readings. Students will be assessed in light of the following criteria:

1. Three quizzes (5 points each)
The quiz covers what has been discussed in the previous lecture.
Make-up quiz is possible but conditional.
   Asking for a leave in advance is needed in order to take the make-up.
2. Mid-term exam (42 points, multiple-choice questions)
3. Final exam (43 points, multiple-choice questions; non-cumulative)

Statistics for this semester:
Quiz 1

Mean:4.8/5
My mark:3.75/5

Quiz 2

Mean:4.3/5
My mark:4.25/5

Quiz 3

Mean:4.8/5
My mark:5/5

Mid term exam

Mean:31.8/42
My mark:31/42

Final Exam

Mean:31.1/43
My mark:31/42

My grade: B
reviews.comment_workload: Quite light. All you have to do is to revise every week for the pop-up quizzes and mid-term examination and final examination.

reviews.author: petrovp
reviews.comment_content: An interesting course for those who want to learn more about the legal system in PRC including various institutions and actors. The course pays attention to some of the major problems that the Chinese legal system faces. Last but not least, the content covers some of the means for social activism (protests, petitions etc...)
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor usually provides handouts, so there is no need to study from other sources (handouts are enough and generally are very well-structured). There are a lot of examples provided which are mainly about controversial cases happened before. There is not much interaction in class, as the professor is speaking most of the time, sometimes can be a bit monotonous but in general it is an interesting class. His stance towards the PRC government is relatively critical and some students may not like it.
reviews.comment_grading: A good grade is not difficult to get. There are mid-term and final exams which are MC. The MC questions are usually pretty straight-forwards, as they require memorizing the handouts. There are three pop-up quizes (5% each and 15% in total). Each quiz covers the topic discussed the week before and requires a short written answer to a question. The first quiz is early around week 3 or 4 while the other two quizes are after the midterm. If a person studies regularly he/she will get 4 or 5 (5 is the max score) on the quizes. The exams are also easy unless a person does not make careless mistakes.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty relaxed. I think it is enough spending around 30 minutes to revise the handouts every time before class in order to be prepared.

reviews.author: lonelyguy
reviews.title: 好靚grade
reviews.comment_content:
Mostly are related to Chinese political issues, NPC, policies and some social issues happened in China. Actually, the topic is interesting with many cases or news included. You will really learn some new insights from this course. Most interestingly, he is a Mainlander but he sometimes also challenges the Chinese system.

Week 1 Introduction: law and society in China
Week 2 Introduction to legal institutions in China
Week 3 Legal workers in China
Week 4 Citizens’ use of law in China (I)
Week 5 Citizens’ use of law in China (II)
Week 6 Suing the government in China
Week 7 Law enforcement in China
Week 8 Appeals and justice in China
Week 9 Petitions and justice in China
Week 10 Media and justice in China
Week 11 The People’s Congress
Week 12 Lawyers in China
Week 13 To the Court or to the Street: Social Protests in China

Exams are not cumulative.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Can see that he is very knowledgable in this topic. He has done much research regarding social protest, laws, political issues in China.

He has a Mainland accent in English but his words are bearable most of the time. BUT, his teaching is boring af. You will easily fall asleep during class, the classroom is still very full though. No attendance is taken.
reviews.comment_grading:
好好grade, 不過要鬥小心, 1題MC就等於1% course grade

Mid Term and final are supposed in MC format, but the final exam was changed to the 2-hour open-book essay exam. MC questions are so straightforward. Just copied from the lecture notes.

Statistics:
5% Quiz 1: 4.5/5 (Mean: 4.6)
5% Quiz 2: 5/5 (Mean: 4.8)
(Quiz 3: cancelled, 5% moved to final exam %)
42% MT: 34/42 (Mean: 30.99, SD: around 6)
48% Final: 44.5/48 (Mean: 40.93 SD: 3.56)
Total: 88% (predict B+ or A- only)

Grade: A  多謝永順哥 :))
reviews.comment_workload:
Nearly no workload unless there is a quiz and exam coming. This semester he did not tell us the date of the quizzes, but you can predict when the quiz is coming. Just attend the quizzes and exam are okay. You can skip the lectures if you are willing to read the lecture notes afterwards.

No project, no attendance, no participation, no essay (special to this semester)

仲唔reg呢科!?

reviews.author: Mcdreamy
reviews.title: 都幾好GRADE
reviews.comment_content:
教中國D制度,法治,司法之類
上完我反而覺得知道更多中國既黑暗野
reviews.comment_teaching:
有大陸口音
基本上唔洗上堂,只返考pop up quiz個堂就ok,
如果pop quiz冇返可以email 補考
reviews.comment_grading:
幾好
d題目mc,好直接,照背note就ok, ppt唔考,但d reading都考幾多,同埋套電影真係會考,pop quiz都好簡單
本身有3個pop up quiz,但因為停課,所以考得兩個,而且final 變左打essay, open book, 係屋企做,都係照copy,好易
quiz 1 :4.5/5, mean 4.6
quiz 2 : 5/5 , mean 4.8
midterm: 34/42, mean: 31.4
final: 42/48 , mean 40.93, sd: 3.56
over all: B+
reviews.comment_workload: 近乎冇,只係溫pop up quiz, 考前一星期會講有quiz

reviews.author: ccky
reviews.comment_content: 主要都係中國社會政治+法制情況，講下現代中國司法機構，法律，傳媒等等，會涉及一d大陸嘅黑暗面，都幾有趣。其中兩堂會播電影《秋菊打官司》，midterm都會考幾題電影入面講嘅情節，問嘅係D濕碎嘢，所以建議睇。
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor內地人英文有口音但可以聽得明，教書都幾流暢，不過上堂模式主要都係佢單方面講書，所以都幾多人走堂。
reviews.comment_grading:
4個quizzes，每個有MC+short Q
1個Midterm+1個final exam都係MC，全部都係堂上考完，好處應該係final可以多咗時間溫其他科，壞處係midterm+final時間好可能會撞正趕assignments/project deadlines 高峰期。
個人覺得幾好grade，MC題目非常直接，照抄notes字眼，照住背就ok，我兩次都係考前溫一日書，最後A咗。不過一定要留心notes入面d graph，真係會問的。
reviews.comment_workload: 極少workload，無assignment/project，reading可以只睇會考嘅個d，大家有信心可以全走堂自學只返quiz+exam都得。

reviews.author: Bon*2
reviews.title: Good grade cc if u have good memory
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1   Introduction: law and society in China

Week 2   Introduction to legal institutions in China  

Week 3   Legal workers in China  

Week 4   Citizens’ use of law in China (I)

Week 5   Citizens’ use of law in China (II)

Week 6   Suing the government in China  

Week 7   Law enforcement in China

Week 8.  Appeals and justice in China

Week 9   Petitions and justice in China

Week 10   Media and justice in China

Week 11   The People’s Congress

Week 12    Lawyers in China

Week 13    To the Court or to the Street: Social Protests in China
reviews.comment_teaching: He has a little bit Mainland accent but is still ok to understand. He includes lots of examples to help clarify the concepts in the lecture but those examples usually don't need to be tested in the midterm and final. He puts all things needed in the lecture notes so just revise the lecture notes but not the PPT.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is quite good. All quizzes and exams are MCs.
3 pop up quizzes --- 15%
Quiz 1 (mean 4.1) 5/5 ---- usually on week 3 or 4
Quiz 2 (mean 4)    5/5
Quiz 3 (mean 4.7) 5/5
Midterm (mean 30.4) 35/42
Final (mean 33.1) 33/43
Overall: 83%
I got an A- in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite low.

Although the first pop-up quiz is a real pop-up quiz, you could still guess some questions by your common sense. You just need to revise the lecture notes taught last week before the pop-up quizzes. Just 30 minutes to 1 hour is already enough.

I just simply ditch all the classes after the first quiz. The first quiz will be on week 3 or 4. You could then predict when will be the next 2 quizzes. Just make sure you attend the pop-up quizzes to get the 5%. If you have revised briefly, there should be no problem for you to score 4.5 or above marks.

RMB to read the readings if you want to get an A range, he really tests those readings in the midterm and final. They may consist 1-3 questions per passage.

reviews.author: david0314
reviews.title: Good grade course! Recommend!
reviews.comment_content: Topics are about the legal institutions, promulgation and the implementation of laws in China. I personally find them very interesting because Cai does delve into the lesser-known aspects of the Chinese law. I also love how uncensored this course is - it does reflect the political, social and legal realities of China. Although there is 'law' in the course title, you don't need to actually know Chinese law. It's more about the culture and how law interacts with society. Generally, if don't extremely hate law, you'll be fine.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lectures are not interactive so there is no stress. The lecture notes are very well-structured and easily digestible, so much so that I would say you don't need to attend any lectures (I personally only attended a few anyways). He presented ideas with a lot of case studies and examples so if you're interested in the course content you'll find the lectures interesting. Generally, good and clear teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grade. There are three pop-up quizzes that you can take online. 5/5 in all of them.

Mid term: 41/42
Exam: 42/43
Mid term and exam are all MCs.

Total: 98/100
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is very small. Just spend 2 days revising the lecture notes and you'll be good to go. If your goal is A or above, make sure to finish the assigned readings (he'll tell you which readings that he'll test you on before MT/exam) and memorise the main points.

reviews.author: nayrB
reviews.title: A bit competitive course
reviews.comment_content:
環繞中國法制
講解每一個機關的效能及局限
例如：
各級人大會議
公安
各級法院
檢察院
同時提及國内法律相關的爭議事件
例如：
强行清拆
法院舞弊
冤案
reviews.comment_teaching:
有d monotone，典型内地口音
但係永順哥 d 英文其實幾易明
想穩 A range要上堂
因爲考試題目答案 ge interpretation 係根據 lecture
reviews.comment_grading:
quiz 1 5/5
quiz 2 5/5
quiz 3 5/5
mid term 40.5/42
final 34/43

over all A-， 剛剛好touch 倒 ,低0.5 都變 B+
呢個分上年應該有 A
但online sem d 人比較competitive
今個sem 有frd overall 87 B+
reviews.comment_workload:
lecture notes 好快溫完
要chur A range 一定要望埋 readings
要讀完所有reading唔係一件容易ge 事

reviews.author: twbr
reviews.comment_content: 如course title，成個course係講中國嘅社會狀況，政府架構同埋法律，會介紹下人大，唔同政府部門，又會講下rural同urban嘅情況有咩唔同，會睇一齣戲－秋菊打官司，分12份lecture notes，midterm final各考6份non-cumulative，死記硬背多，有留意中國時事嘅都會有幫助。
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor講英文有口音，但都算係清晰易明。
reviews.comment_grading:
正正常常，冇驚喜亦冇失望。
我嘅分:
Quizzes: 13.25/15 (5% each)
Midterm: 36/42 (mean: 31.5, s.d.: 5.7)
Final: 32/43 (mean: 31, s.d.: 5)
Grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
算係好低架喇 :D
3 Pop quizzes:
1. 1個midterm前，2個midterm後
2. 每個5%，今個sem format係1mc(1%) + 1sq(4%)

Midterm/Final:
1. 主要係考lecture notes，professor上堂會講好多cases幫助我哋明白concepts，但係冇include喺lecture notes度嘅就唔會考。
2. 每個lecture都會有相應嘅readings，考試佢會講明考邊幾份所以唔駛全部睇晒，今個sem就係midterm final各考3-4份readings。
3. midterm final都係in-class，好嘅係exam period輕鬆啲，唔好嘅係有機會sem尾撞晒唔同paper嘅deadlines，冇乜時間溫。

Course content算容易handle，要留意嘅係professor問好多hard facts同埋可以問到好深入，數據佢都會問。另外pop quiz都唔係次次前一堂提我哋，今個sem第3個係真pop quiz。

reviews.author: Ter8899
reviews.title: very interesting
reviews.comment_content:
Very interesting content. it's about the CCP and Chinese law with real cases.

Of course, there're also some dark things about China involved, so if you are very sensitive, you may want to reconsider before taking this course.

You'll get what you expected if you are interested in China's politics and law.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good and honest teaching overall. I enjoyed the lecture most of the time. And the professor welcomes questions after class.

Clear explanation, I thought the accent would be the problem at first, but it didn't affect the delivery after all.

I like he talked about his personal experience and opinion on the issue sometime.
reviews.comment_grading:
Three pop quizzes. All with one MC and one short question. Mit-term and Final (both MC).

That's basically all the work.

I got an average on three quizzes.
Mit-term: 35/42
Final: 33/43
Final Grade: B

Nothing to complain about. Average effort, average grade.

Even if you got a really bad grade (which won't happen if you pay a little bit of attention to the lectures) on the exams, he will make up for it by giving you extra work.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light.

reviews.author: wantgoodgrade
reviews.title: Low workload course
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture 1: Introduction to law and society in China
Lecture 2: Legal institutions in China
Lecture 3: Legal agents in China
Lecture 4: Citizens' use of law in China
Lecture 5: Civil disputes
Lecture 6: Suing the government in China
Lecture 7: Law enforcement in China
Lecture 8: Checks within the legal departments
Lecture 9: Petitions in China
Lecture 10: News media in China
Lecture 11: The People's Congress in China
Lecture 12: Lawyers in China
reviews.comment_teaching:
he speaks slowly. Sometimes the accent may be hard to understand. But overall is okay as he provides many examples for students for reference.

I didn't go to every class due to busy workload from other courses.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 Quizzes. I got all 5/5

Midterm : 38/42
Final : 41/43

Grade: A
If I got 1 more mark from midterm or final, I could get A+ :((( very sad
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload. Just memorize the things in the notes.

Details may be examined too. Such as the highest ratio of police among the population etc.. As long as you take some days to revise the exam, you can get A range

reviews.author: kath521
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture 1: Introduction to law and society in China
Lecture 2: Legal institutions in China
Lecture 3: Legal agents in China
Lecture 4: Citizens' use of law in China

reviews.comment_teaching: He taught along with the ppt. His voice is a bit soft and sometimes I can't hear it clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1: 3.5/5
Quiz 2: 3.5/5
Quiz 3: 4/5
mid-term: 31/42
final: 32/43
grade: B
reviews.comment_workload: light workload. Only three quizzes, one mid-term and one final. There are a lot of things to memorize, and you have to read the reading materials in detail (he will tell you which reading materials will be tested).

reviews.author: Aud
reviews.title: A course about memorising
reviews.comment_content:
not gonna mention the details again
I personally like the course a lot since I'm interested in the topic. That's why I can memorise content quickly
reviews.comment_teaching:
He's actually reading the PowerPoint but also shared some extra examples(which were not tested)
Except for his soft voice, everything was great
reviews.comment_grading:
quit great(I'm not sure tho)
quizzes@3: 15/15
--quizzes include MC and SQ, usually one MC with one SQ, the mean was quite high (ard 4). If you missed the quiz, you could ask for a makeup quiz, but it would be a summary of a given reading(not sure, I heard from my friend)
--for this semester, students can choose to attend classes online or offline, prof. allowed students to finish the first two quizzes online but not for mt/final and the last quiz
MT/Final: are all MCQ
midterm: 39/42
-->mean: 31.52 Median: 32 UQ: 36 LQ: 29
(around 5 questions are related to the movie: the Story of Qiu Ju, quite interesting, you are able to answer all questions if you pay attention to watch the movie, there is no need to remember the details)

final: 40/43
-->Mean: 32.29 Median: 33 UQ: 37 LQ: 29

overall 94/100->A
a bit disappointed with the grade and emailed the prof. He told me there were 5 people scoring 94 hence he gave one A+ only (94.75)
Have to be VERY VERY VERY VERY careful when you are doing your exam as one mc=one point of your grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 pop quizzes
1 midterm
1 final
super light, just memorise everything in his notes, he will even test u the data/graphs (not the exact number but sth like: xxx rate has (slightly/largely) (increased/decreased))
final is held in the last class

reviews.author: ctc
reviews.title: Very Good
reviews.comment_content:
非常多內容
但是基本上只要有背note 就可以應付所有quiz exam
quiz是在課堂上進行的 但quiz的時間不會提前通知

This course introduces to students basic knowledge about the operation of the Chinese legal system or legal institutions. It examines how laws are used in the social, economic, and political activities of the Chinese people.
Learning outcomes

After taking this introductory course, students are expected to: (1) know about Chinese legal institutions and their functions; (2): be familiar with the ways legal disputes are resolved in China; (3) understand the mechanisms that can be exploited by citizens or other social actors to seek justice in Chinese society; and (4) be able to analyze basic legal issues in China.

Lectures

Week 1 Introduction: law and society in China

Wang Shaoguang, “The Problems of State Weakness,” Journal of Democracy, vol. 14, no. 1 (2003), pp. 36-42.



“The Cultural Revolution”

http://members.fortunecity.com/stalinmao/China/Cultural/Cultural.html





Week 2 Introduction to legal institutions in China

“China’s Judicial System: people’s courts, procuratorates, and public security,”
http://www.olemiss.edu/courses/pol324/chnjudic.htm



Richard Wong, “Why China chose the German instead of English legal system,”
South China Morning Post, October 13, 2015.





Week 3 Legal workers in China

Peerenboom, China’s Long March toward Rule of Law, pp. 290-302.



“Judging judges: To help build “the rule of law”, China is demoting judges,”
The Economists Sep 26th 2015





Week 4 Citizens’ use of law in China (I)

Yongshun Cai, “Social Conflicts and Modes of Action in China,” China Journal, vol. 59 (2008), pp. 62-82.



Zhang Shouzhi, “Litigation and enforcement in China: overview,” http://global.practicallaw.com/8-502-1965





Week 5   Citizens’ use of law in China (II)

Video: “The Story of Qiu Ju” (秋菊打官司) (English Subtitle).



Randall Peerenboom, China’s Long March toward Rule of Law, pp. 280-295.



Philip P. Pan, “In China, Turning the Law into the People’s Protector,” Washington Post, December 28, 2004; Page A01







Week 6 Suing the government in China

Peerenboom, China’s Long March toward Rule of Law, pp. 414-424.



Kevin O’Brien and Lianjiang Li, “Suing the local state: Administrative Litigation in Rural China,” China Journal, vol. 51 (2004), pp. 75-96.





Week 7 Law enforcement in China

Cindy Chu, “Human trafficking and Smuggling in China,” Journal of Contemporary China, vol. 20, no. 68 (2011), pp. 39-52.



Suggested reading:

Donald, Clarke, “The Execution of Civil Judgments in China,” China Quarterly, vol. 141 (1995), pp. 65 –81.



Xin He, “Debt-Collection in the Less Developed Regions of China: An Empirical Study from a Basic-Level Court in Shaanxi Province,” The China Quarterly, no. 206,





Seeking Justice in China: Redress Mechanisms



Week 8. Appeals and justice in China

Peerenboom, China’s Long March toward Rule of Law, pp. 302-312.



Jim Yardley, “Desperate Search for Justice: One Man vs. China,” The New York Times, 12 November 2005.



(Mid-Term Exam; it covers Lecture 1 to Lecture 6, second class of week 8)







Week 9 Petitions and justice in China

Yongshun Cai, “Managed Participation in China,” Political Science Quarterly, vol. 119, no. 3 (2004), pp. 425-452.



Suggested reading:

“The extrajudicial execution of Cao Haixin, a good citizen of Zhengzhou,” translated from Chinese by Joe Chung.





Week 10 Media and justice in China

Ben Liebman, “Changing media, changing courts” in Susan Shirk (ed.), Changing Media, Changing China (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2011), pp. 150-174.







Week 11 The People’s Congress

“The National People’s Congress,” http://www.china.org.cn/english/27743.htm



Suggested reading:

Pitman Potter, The Chinese Legal System (London: Routledge, 2001), pp. 16-26.





Week 12  Lawyers in China

Yongshun Cai and Songcai Yang, “State Power and Unbalanced Legal Development in China,” Journal of Contemporary China, vol. 14, no. 42 (2005), pp. 117-134.





Week 13 To the Court or to the Street: Social Protests in China
Chen, Chih-Jou Jay, “Growing Social Unrest and Emergent Protest Groups in China”, editor(s): Hsin-Huang Michael Hsiao and Cheng-Yi Lin, Rise of China: Beijing’s Strategies and Implications for the Asia-Pacific (London and New York: Routledge, 2009), pp. 87-106.
reviews.comment_teaching: 教授聲音比較小，需要坐前一點才能聽清楚
reviews.comment_grading: 很可以
reviews.comment_workload: 除了quiz midterm final 沒有其他功課

quiz 2: 5/5
quiz 3: 4/5

only 3 quizzes, one mt, and one final
but you have to memorize everything in the lecture notes before the exams

reviews.author: carolyn hong
reviews.comment_content:
General:
-China's political-legal system
-Ways to resolve legal disputes in China
-Basic legal issues in China analysis
[with many examples]

Topics:
1. Introduction: law and society in China
2. Introduction to legal institutions in China  
3. Legal workers in China
4. Citizens’ use of law in China (I)
5. Citizens’ use of law in China (II)
6. Suing the government in China  
7. Law enforcement in China
8. Appeals and justice in China
9. Petitions and justice in China
10. Media and justice in China
11. The People’s Congress
12. Lawyers in China
13. To the Court or to the Street: Social Protests in China
reviews.comment_teaching:
-Clear ppt (Prof will mention which example will be included in exam) and doc (lecture notes for pop-up quizzes and exams)
-Teaching read from ppt
reviews.comment_grading:
-3 Quizzes                                                      {15%}
-Mid-term: Topic 1-6                         [42 MC]  {42%}
-Exam: Topic 7-13(non-cumulative) [43 MC]  {43%}
reviews.comment_workload:
-Quizzes (1 before mid-term, 2 after mid-term)
   -- from doc (previous lecture topic)
-Mid-term (Week 8)
  -- from doc+ppt+required readings
-Exam (Week 13)
  -- from doc+ppt+required readings

reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has a bit accent but it's not hard to understand what he says. He tried to use a lot of examples to help you understand the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think it's very good.
1. Three pop-up quizzes (5 points each)
2. Mid-term exam (42 points, multiple-choice )
3. Final exam (43 points, multiple-choice)

Overall: 89.5/100
I got A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Very light workload compared to other courses.
You just need to attend the lecture (though it's 9 am) so that you won't miss the pop quiz.
There isn't any assignment or group project.
The midterm and final exams are just MC questions. Spending a few days to revise will be fine. Read the readings if you wanna get A range.

reviews.author: stsum
reviews.title: chill but not very good grade
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching:
a little bit accent but is ok to understand
not much intereaction in class
include many real life cases for each topic, not abstact and quite interesting
reviews.comment_grading:
not good not bad
midterm and final slightly above mean
quiz slightly lower than mean
-> B
(mean is really high for this semester)
reviews.comment_workload:
chill
only 2 exams and 3 pop quizzes
exam: all mc, quite straight forward
**Readings are important if you aim an A range since the lecture part is very simple. There are only 3 required readings for each exam but are quite long and difficult.
pop quiz :only lecture notes are tested, include mc and short questions, not difficult (i think most ppl get full marks)

reviews.author: Eitou
reviews.title: light workload course
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly introduce Chinese legal system and legal institutions. The course also cover topics like law enforcement, petitions, and social protests.

You will know what are the issues faced by different departments and how conflicts occur between citizens and government agencies, which are not usually seen on the news.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite interesting if you are not get lost in the professor’s mainland accent. He gives many examples during lectures, those are very helpful for you to have a better understanding of the topic, although most of them are not tested.
reviews.comment_grading:
All MC questions for both exams.

three quizzes: 15%
mid-term: 42%
final: 43%
reviews.comment_workload: Nearly no workload, all you need to do is go through lecture notes and readings before two exams, it won't cost you a day if you attend every lecture or you already have some knowledge about Chinese society. Remember to watch the film (The Story of Qu Ju) if you miss it in class.

reviews.author: Ged
reviews.title: A useful course for students unless they are vested interests of CCP structure.
reviews.comment_content: Introduction to every aspects regarding the legal system, power structure, the party and the CCP government. You can learn and grasp the reason and rationale of the policies and decisions made by central and local level of CCP committees, governments and legal agencies, which is very important since many examples have shown that without understanding the officials and CCP, it almost impossible to do any successful business in China.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof.Cai has taught this class for many years, so it seems that he doesn't make preparation before class. However, he can still bring you the main part and knowledge of his lectures clearly because he has taught these snuffs many times.
reviews.comment_grading: Curve grading, quite fair. 3 pop up quizzes+midterm and final exam, all MCs this semester. It should be noted that each questions is equivalent to 1% to your overall grade (that means in total 100 MCs), so be extremely careful. About 90% overall is A. Maybe A+ cutoff is 95%. Quite competitve since many Mainlanders who are more familiar with CCP enrolled in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: No workload except before the midterm and final exam. Be careful and review the lecture notes meticulously since any small details like some statistics figures may be tested. Also, Cai will also provide you some readings for each lecture. Try to read as many as you can because some of these readings will also be tested.

reviews.author: busi trash
reviews.title: 0 workload and extremely easy cc
reviews.comment_content: see others,
reviews.comment_teaching:
passionate to teach, tell us a lot of real situations and examples that are not tested in the exam, just to let us know more about chinese politics,

not afraid to tell something bad about CCP, so no worries

the chinese accent is not good tho,
reviews.comment_grading:
3 pop-up quizzes -> 15%     above mean on all quizzes
midterm                -> 42%     above 2 sd
final exam             -> 43%     sd is not released, but similar situation with midterm, i score almost full while the mean is about 30/42

final grade   ->   94/100  ->  A

lil bit disappointed :(
reviews.comment_workload:
extremely light workload

pop-up quizzes only involves one mc q and a short q, test the contents of last week, really wont have notification, (by my observation, it would only be tested on the second class of a week before the class ended, so you could only attend the second class weekly, and study the contents last week to prepare for the pop-up quizzes)

mt & final: all mc, (i only spent 1/3 of time to finish and check), if you are good at memorizing thing, you could easily kill the exam, the amount of documents is not huge, however, sometimes the question are too specific, even asking you some figure

reviews.author: Jimmy Chen
reviews.comment_content:
The course is about the Chinese legal system and institutions.
You will be familiar with the content if you are from China.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very interesting.
But the course content is about the social issues that happened 10 years ago, so rather outdated.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is very good.
I got higher than the means for all exams, and I got an A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not very huge.
You only need to read the readings carefully. The content in the ppts is not very hard.
The exams will cover the readings, so you need to read the readings. But the questions in the exams are almost identical to the content mentioned in the readings, so I think the only workload is the readings.

reviews.author: Eclaris
reviews.title: Good Grade Course!!!
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1   Introduction: law and society in China
Week 2   Introduction to legal institutions in China  
Week 3   Legal workers in China  
Week 4   Citizens’ use of law in China (I)
Week 5   Citizens’ use of law in China (II)
Week 6   Suing the government in China  
Week 7   Law enforcement in China
Week 8  Appeals and justice in China
Week 9   Petitions and justice in China
Week 10   Media and justice in China
Week 11   The People’s Congress
Week 12    Lawyers in China
Week 13    To the Court or to the Street: Social Protests in China

Didn't cover the last one due to lack of time in this semester.

Exams' content are non-cumulative.
reviews.comment_teaching: Mainland professor, have accent in English but acceptable. His pace of speaking is pretty slow so you can catch up the content pretty easily. He provides a lot of examples for you to have a better understanding towards the issues. I think he has the heart in teaching.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1: 5/5   mean: 4.7/5
Quiz 2: 4.75/5   mean: 4.8/5
Quiz 3: 5/5  mean: 4.8/5
Mid-term: 38.5/42   mean: 34.8/42
Final: 36.5/43   mean: 35.2/43
* The MC and short questions are pretty straightforward, so be careful in answering the questions.

Grade: A- ( I screwed up the final. )
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely light.
Just revise 3 pop-up quizzes and 2 exams (open book exams in this semester).
Read the required readings for exams (4+4) which he would tell you before exams.
Only the content covered in the lecture notes would be tested, you don't have to revise the PPT.

reviews.author: mini1999
reviews.title: Recommended online course
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1 Introduction: law and society in China
Week 2 Introduction to legal institutions in China
Week 3 Legal workers in China
Week 4 Citizens’ use of law in China (I)
Week 5 Citizens’ use of law in China (II)
Week 6 Suing the government in China
Week 7 Law enforcement in China
Week 8 Appeals and justice in China

Week 10 Media and justice in China

Week 12 Lawyers in China

Week 13 既教唔切
reviews.comment_teaching:
like listening to stories during class, teaching is not boring
but i think it's okay not to listen to class because the exams are based on lecture notes and readings only, you can do revision on your own. unless you don't understand by just reading the notes, you can refer to the ppt, but the ppt will not be examined.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 pop-up quizzes (@5%, total 15%)
1 midterm (42%) 30mc + few short q
1 final (43%) 30mc + few short q

3 quizzes: 15/15
midterm: 40/42
final: 36.5/43

final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
many readings before exam, but it's fine if you read them beforehand and jot down the notes so that it won't be too tough right before the exams. must do the readings coz they will be examined! impossible to find the answers during exams.

3 pop quizzes to check attendance, but they are easy as long as you just read through the lecture notes before every class. even if you don't read, you can find the answer during the quizzes.

i guess it is of light workload because it is in online mode, so that every thing goes open book and you don't have to spend too much time reciting the materials.

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: Easy SA CC with tens of CCP teens 刷Grade一流
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers how law are used in China under CCP control in  economic, social, political and legal perspectives. The major law and party related issues are addressed, examples including the judiciary system, law enforcement, lawyers in China, petitions, the People's Congress etc. Some social phenomenon before and after the Cultural Revolution and Reform and opening-up policies are also covered, like medical dispute, house demolitation, rural reform etc.

The overall content are not difficult to handle. The only thing good  or bad at the same time is that the examples illustrated are quite long time ago, probably in the early 2000s, I would say it can be good to know the social changes in China in our childhood days, but the bad thing is the social conditions and international relation of China keeps changing in the past 10 years, it would be better to cover more such examples to demonstrate the concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor has some Mainland accent but still not hard to follow his presentation. The lecture is sometimes boring given that he follows the lecture presentation to cover the key points and illustrates different cases during the class. The professor is critical with sufficient supporting evidences.

Basically you can treat the lecture in a casual way given that the notes are well to the point which is sufficient enough to prepare for the exam. Some required readings are necessary for every exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course is competitive given that the exams are all open book and there are a lot of CCP "little pinky" joining this course with "sufficient" understanding of their "dearest party". A subtle mistake may cost you 1 point loss for the entire course so just be careful.

The exam are not cumulative and cover the content for the first  and second half of the course with assigned readings respectively. Each exam includes 30 MCQs and 3 Short essay questions.

My result:
Quiz x3
5/5, 5/5, 5/5
Midterm 40/42
Final 38/43

Overall 93%
Grade A

If you expect a good grade with low workload, this course is a good choice during online semester. Don't be stupid sticking to those notoriously large class which strictly follows the grade distribution where the Business students or seniors take advantages.
reviews.comment_workload:
The key workload is to understand well the lecture notes and read all the required readings for the exam. The content are not hard given that you pay some efforts some days before the midterm and final  exam.

3 pop up quizzes are given and covered the content probably from the previous lecture, just some simple short questions where you can refer to the notes.

reviews.author: 快樂肥仔
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1   Introduction: law and society in China
Week 2   Introduction to legal institutions in China  
Week 3   Legal workers in China  
Week 4   Citizens’ use of law in China (I)
Week 5   Citizens’ use of law in China (II)
Week 6   Suing the government in China  
Week 7   Law enforcement in China
Week 8  Appeals and justice in China
Week 9   Petitions and justice in China
Week 10   Media and justice in China
Week 11   The People’s Congress
Week 12    Lawyers in China
Week 13    To the Court or to the Street: Social Protests in China

You can capture a basic understanding of the Chinese legal and political system after taking this course. It analyses the issues from a relatively objective perspective so you do not have to worry about being brainwashed.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The lectures are a bit boring, but skipping the lessons will not affect your performance in the exams since both lecture notes and slides can be found on Canvas and the key concepts have already been explained clearly in the notes.

Please note that the professor and TA would not give you the answer keys of the exams, so you cannot appeal or ask for the correct answers after knowing your scores.
reviews.comment_grading:
The mean is super high as it's an open book exam.

Midterm MC: (30)
Mean: 25.8 High: 30    Low: 11
Midterm short q.: (12)
Mean: 9 High: 12 Low: 4

Final MC: (30)
Mean: 24.1 High: 30    Low: 16
Final short q.: (13)
Mean: 11.1 High: 12.5 Low: 8

The midterm mc questions are not difficult and you may just use command F to find the answers from the notes (tho it may be a little bit slow), but some of the keywords are changed in final exams, making it more challenging to find the answers you need.

As mentioned above, it's an open book exam, so it may not be fair to those who study hard for the course. Some keywords may not be defined clearly in the MC questions, but it's hard for you to appeal when they are not giving you the correct answers.

If you just want to look for a social science course to fulfill the common core requirement, this course will be a good option for you. But I don't think it will be a nice course for those who aim at getting an A range.
reviews.comment_workload: Not heavy at all. 2 exams and 3 pop quizzes.

reviews.author: a132

Journal, no. 48 (2002), pp. 139-154.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor tells the concepts clearly with ppt.He tries to use a lot of interesting examples to help you understandings.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is quite good.Above mean can get at least B or above.

Grading:
1.Three pop-up quiz(5 marks each)
2.Mid-term exam (42 marks,mc)
3.Final exam (43 marks,mc)
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not much.Only lecture notes and readings (only three required readings) are required.The video watched in class is also tested.Pop-up quiz will usually be reminded before.

reviews.author: Step_wyl
reviews.comment_content:
basic knowledge about the operation of the Chinese legal system or legal institutions
examines how laws are used in the social, economic, and political activities of the Chinese people
a movie will be played in class
reviews.comment_teaching:
relaxing lesson and the prof is nice
ppt will be shown in class but no need to memorize
provides students with lecture notes and easy to understand
reviews.comment_grading:
Three quizzes (pop up, cover what has been discussed in the previous lecture)

Mid-term exam (mc)

Final exam (mc, non-cumulative)
reviews.comment_workload: nearly zero, only reading materials

reviews.author: iwantsleep
reviews.comment_content: mainly learn about the Chinese legal system or legal institutions. It will be quite boring if you are not interested in the Chinese legal system. A movie will be shown in 2 lectures. Some questions about the movie will be tested but those are simple questions. You may read the wiki about that movie before the test and it will be fine to answer the questions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Sometimes he just read out the ppt. There are many slides for each topic. But what we how to revise is the lecture notes. He will include the main point in the lecture notes for each topic. And there will be questions about the readings in examinations.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1: 5/5   mean: 4.8/5
Quiz 2: 5/5   mean: 4.3/5
Quiz 3: 4.75/5  mean: 4.8/5

Mid-term: 30/42  mean: 31.8/42
Final: 30/43  mean: 31.1/43

Final grade: B
reviews.comment_workload:
very light workload. Just have 3 pop up quiz.
one before midterm and two after midterm.
The first one is really pop up quiz. But for the second and third quiz, prof. reminded us to revise one lecture before.
And the mid-term and final are in-class examinations. You may not have enough time to revise for the final exam since you may be busy at the end of the semester.

reviews.author: schuinmg
reviews.comment_content:
我自己覺得啲內容都幾有趣既，唔太悶，不過要背野
mid-term前：
Week 1 Introduction: law and society in China
Week 2 Introduction to legal institutions in China
Week 3 Legal workers in China
Week 4 Citizens’ use of law in China (I)
Week 5 Citizens’ use of law in China (II)
Week 6 Suing the government in China
Mid-term後：
Week 7 Law enforcement in China
Week 8. Appeals and justice in China
Week 9 Petitions and justice in China
Week 10 Media and justice in China
Week 11 The People’s Congress
Week 12  Lawyers in China
Week 13 To the Court or to the Street: Social Protests in China
Mid-term前有一堂半會播套電影，記得睇啦，mid-term會問的，大概3-4條mc，唔睇都google下內容啦
Mid-term同final除左考lecture notes仲會考required reading，每次大概3份到，都幾多字下...好似我咁放棄唔睇真係會後悔，因為都會問的...
reviews.comment_teaching:
大陸prof，有啲口音，要認真少少聽如果唔係會唔知佢講到邊...
都幾有心教既，但基本上都係跟住ppt講下，唔上堂都OK
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 15%, Mid-term 42% Final 43%
我覺得幾好grade 成個sem淨係上過兩堂( sor 10半堂太早我真係起唔到身...) midterm同final都係前一日先溫都搞得點
有3 個pop-up quiz 一個midterm前兩個midterm後
淨係有考到第一個pop-up quiz，個人覺得啲題目簡單直接，好容易答，1條MC，1條Short Q，輕鬆滿分
mid-term後我基本上冇上過堂，miss曬兩個pop-up quiz，不過send個e-mail比prof話要make-up就ok，會係寫2-3頁關於一篇reading既summary，一樣輕鬆。
Quiz 1 5/5 (Mean:4.8)
Quiz 2 4.5/5 (Mean:4.3)
Quiz 3 4.75/5 (Mean: 4.8)
Mid-Term 32/42 (Mean:31.8)
Final 32/43 (Mean:31.1)
最後B 真係算係咁
reviews.comment_workload: 基本上冇乜workload pop-up quiz可以候補 淨係溫midterm同final就ok 溫曬啲lecture notes都足夠應付

reviews.author: Ymy
reviews.comment_content:
lecture1: introduction to law and society in china
lecture2: legal institutions in china
lecture3: legal agents in china
lecture4: citizen's use of laws in china
lecture5: civil disputes
lecture6: suing the government in china
lecture7: law enforcement in china
lecture8: checks within the legal department
lecture9: petition in china
lecture10: news media in china
lecture11: the people's congress in china
lecture12: lawyers in china
lecture13: to the court or to the street? seeking justice through protest

One lecture notes for one week and there will be a week for watching a film called “The Story of Qiu Ju” which will also be the content of the exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is very boring and has heavy Mandarin accent English. I think going to lesson has no use as the exam is just reciting lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
1.Three quizzes (5 points each, one mc and one short question)
2.Mid-term exam (42 points, multiple-choice questions)
3.Final exam (43 points, multiple-choice questions; non-cumulative)
Also,each exam also include 3 reading materials. However, the reading materials are too long and I didn't watch them so I got above mean in each exam and finally got B.
reviews.comment_workload: It has no assignment at all except you need to study the quiz before lesson. The quizzes are about the previous lecture notes. He will also remind you that next lesson will have the quizzes during lesson so there is no worry.

reviews.author: Xiao
reviews.comment_content: About the law and it's social,economic and political background during Chinese history.But the course focuses mainly on modern China. The prof gives many cases as examples in the class,however you don't need to remember most of the cases.
reviews.comment_teaching: Honestly speaking,the course is not as interesting as people imagine. The prof teaches as he's always reading the PPT and notes. Unluckily, it's quite difficult to find a clear logical order among the content he lists on the notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 exams and 5 pop-up (actually not pop-up,since he would tell you a week before) quiz. All MC.
Grade is quite good.I got 40/42 in midterm and nearly full mark in final,and achieved an A+.
The questions are straightforward, and ,for many of them,you can just figure out the correct answer with common sense and logic.
reviews.comment_workload:
Review before exams!
Recite ALL content on the notes!

reviews.author: tototo
reviews.comment_content:
quite interesting,
mainly teach about some popular topics in mainland chain
u have already studied most of the topics in your high school.
reviews.comment_teaching:
boring
want to sleep all the time
reviews.comment_grading:
very good
almost get full mark in mid-term
you can absolutely get a good grade if u have recite all the lecture notes
it is not really necessary for you to go through the reference books if u have attended the lecture classes.
the questions of the quizzes, mid-term and final are straight forward.

mid-term: 40/42
final: above 0.75 sd
full marks in all pop-up quiz
finally got A
reviews.comment_workload:
very light
only have 3 pop-up quizzes but actually it is not pop-up at all since the professor always tell you a week before the quiz

reviews.author: cinccccc
reviews.title: good grade with low workload
reviews.comment_content: All interrelated to the legal system of China and how the government exercise the law on the society. There are a bunch of cases to be examined.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof has a strong accent but it's not difficult to pick up. Prof provides us with detailed explanation on each cases and points. His whole teaching is literally based on the handouts which have included most of the points already. However, lessons are not interactive as Prof talks most of the time.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading part is super satisfactory.

Midterm and Final are in MC form. If you have revised all the points from the handouts, you would probably get a super good grade. I got the maximum in midterm and above mean 1sd in final, eventually got an A in this subject.
HARD WORK PAYS OFF!!!
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is trivial. There are 3 quizzes, 1 midterm and 1 final. The quizzes are in Short Answer form; midterm and final are in MC form. Some readings are included in the midterm and final. However, this course won't consume lots of time in revising.

reviews.author: yii_
reviews.comment_content: 內容幾得意 知道多左內地法律情況 例如係要離婚可以搵邊個department處理，Petition的情況，內地人多唔多用law 去seek justice等等, 有好多例子幫你記內容
reviews.comment_teaching:
有時上堂會有啲悶 但好彩prof會講好多例子 有時啲例子幾搞笑
個ppt 同notes 既次序有啲混亂 有時唔知佢講到邊part...
reviews.comment_grading:
超好grade
有3個pop up quiz 每個5分滿分 通常考返quiz前一個星期既野 個quiz有mc, short question 不過好簡單 容易拎4-5分
mid term 同final 都全mc 大約42題MC
reviews.comment_workload:
基本上留心聽書 同考試時睇reading 已經夠
冇group project 冇present 淨係上堂 超輕workload!!!

reviews.author: Ericliys
reviews.title: Good course if you have interest
reviews.comment_content: As title, content mainly about some laws, courts and legal systems, quite interesting as it covers a lot of real-life cases.
reviews.comment_teaching: Not a great english speaker but talks fluently so you can understand without any difficulty. Not much interactions, so only listening and look at his slides and notes.
reviews.comment_grading: Very Good, mean -> B+ already
reviews.comment_workload:
None, only revision before exams and quiz.
No homework at all, and he lets you know 1 week earlier about the quiz, and quiz content is last week's lecture, and questions is straight-forward.
Midterm, final non-accumulative, takes a few days to study all, and he takes the exams in lessons, so doesn't cost you time during study break. Questions also easy and straight-forward.

reviews.author: MS
reviews.title: 低workload之選
reviews.comment_content:
主要係講大陸既法制特點, 社會運動, 政府之間既關係
當中有好多case studies 冤假錯案會交代
堂上會播秋菊打官司 (會考的)
reviews.comment_teaching:
極重普通話口音同
feel到佢對中國法制同社會運動好有研究
但太過單向性
幾乎無台上台下對答
似讀powerpoint多於教書, 哈哈
reviews.comment_grading:
非常好...
2次都低接近1sd都有B range
reviews.comment_workload:
15% 3 pop-up quizzes
40% mid-term
45% final

Pop-up quizzes 顧名思義即係突擊測驗
只係溫notes就夠做唔洗溫lecture powerpoints
notes 內容好少但已經足以應付 (每份大概10版左右)

mid-term同final 全mc
會講明邊d readings唔洗考
但有d readings好多數據同埋d terms好相似好易混淆
最好自己睇多幾次同自己整notes 處理readings資料會好d

reviews.author: 楠哥
reviews.title: 伏科,非對中國法律狀況有興趣建議勿讀
reviews.comment_content:
內容同其他review一樣,按我所知呢幾年都冇變過,詳細內容請睇其他review.

Go find other reviews for your reference if you want to know the content of this course. The content has never changed since the course was opened as I know.
reviews.comment_teaching:
阿sir講書嘅語氣好奇怪,佢係一隻一隻噔出尼,明白可能佢係想講清楚D英文,但係實際好悶又細聲,坐係最後可能更加聽唔到佢講meh,有幾次搞到我差D瞓着,《秋菊打官司》(課堂中會播放嘅一套電影,是考試嘅內容)仲好睇過佢嘅lecture.因此,非對中國法律有興趣以及非自律性努力温書嘅人,不要選擇此科.

The tone of Professor's speech is very strange, he spoke words one by one, I understood that maybe he wanted to speak English to us without his heavy accent, but in reality, his voice is very muffled and soft, and people sitting on the back in theatre may not be able to hear what he says, I almost sleep a few times, "The Story of Qiu Ju" (a movie that will be played in the lecture, which is the content of the exam) is even better than attending his lecture. Therefore, if you are not interested in Chinese law and who are not self-disciplined and hardworking, do not choose this course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quiz 1: 4/5
Quiz 2: 4.5/5
Quiz 3: 4.5/5
Mid-term: 25/42
Final: 20/43
Grade: C-
reviews.comment_workload:
除了咗Pop-up quiz,mid-term,final exam之外,就冇assignment.想攞高grade,建議勤奮讀lecture powerpoint同佢D Reading(Reading 佔 exams都頗重比例)

No Assignment besides the quizzes and exams. Spend more time to read the lecture's powerpoint and readings in order to take a higher grade.

reviews.author: 浩泓
reviews.comment_content: 主要介绍中国政治法律现状，理解党，政府，人民，律师和法治的相互关系。
reviews.comment_teaching: 课上主要讲解ppt，重在帮助你加深理解，ppt的content，exam不会出现
reviews.comment_grading:
一次期中，一次期末，三次quizz
mid：40/42
final：40/43
quiz：14.5/15
最后：A+
reviews.comment_workload: 主要是复习lecture notes和reading，需要很好记忆力，重在细节。

reviews.author: JY_XueBa_Not
reviews.title: RECITE RECITE RECITE
reviews.comment_content:
WARNING: DO NOT CHOOSE THIS COURSE IF YOU ARE BAD AT RECITING!!!

China law and governance .... There are so much corruption and dark history. I am not too interested at reciting all of these.
reviews.comment_teaching:
WARNING: DO NOT CHOOSE THIS COURSE IF YOU ARE BAD AT RECITING!!!

He is boring , just skip class and come back for pop up quiz (ask classmates when the quizzes are)
reviews.comment_grading:
WARNING: DO NOT CHOOSE THIS COURSE IF YOU ARE BAD AT RECITING!!!

Mean is B.
Since I am terrible at reciting, I got below mean for both exams. Ended up C+ (F**K!)
reviews.comment_workload:
WARNING: DO NOT CHOOSE THIS COURSE IF YOU ARE BAD AT RECITING!!!

No workload, 3 predictable pop up quiz that counts for 15% score. You must read and recite the reading materials before exams
